user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketAddrSetPort_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_SocketAddrSetPort_Impl(OS_SockAddr_t *Addr, uint16 PortNum)
{
    in_port_t               sa_port;
    OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *Accessor;

    sa_port  = htons(PortNum);
    Accessor = (OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *)&Addr->AddrData;

    switch (Accessor->sa.sa_family)
    {
        case AF_INET:
            Accessor->sa_in.sin_port = sa_port;
            break;
#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6
        case AF_INET6:
            Accessor->sa_in6.sin6_port = sa_port;
            break;
#endif
        default:
            return OS_ERR_BAD_ADDRESS;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_SocketAddrSetPort_Impl:
typedef struct
{
    size_t            ActualLength; /**< @brief Length of the actual address data */
    OS_SockAddrData_t AddrData;     /**< @brief Abstract Address data */
} OS_SockAddr_t
...
typedef union
{
    char               data[OS_SOCKADDR_MAX_LEN];
    struct sockaddr    sa;
    struct sockaddr_in sa_in;
#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6
    struct sockaddr_in6 sa_in6;
#endif
} OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t
...
typedef uint16_t  uint16
...
typedef int32_t   int32
...
#define OS_ERR_BAD_ADDRESS (-34)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
int32 OS_SocketAddrSetPort_Impl(OS_SockAddr_t *Addr, uint16 PortNum)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The Addr parameter is intentionally non-const because the function writes the port into Addr->AddrData (e.g. Accessor->sa_in.sin_port = ...). Since the pointer target is modified, it should not be const; thus there is no opportunity to make it const-qualified.
